events.title: The First Migration to Abyssinia
events.details:
## Reasons for the Migration to Abyssinia

Umm Salamah (may Allah be pleased with her) narrated:
> "When Mecca became unbearable for us, and the companions of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) were persecuted and put to trial, and they saw the affliction and tribulation that befell them in their religion, and that the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) could not repel it from them, while the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) was protected by his people and his uncle, nothing he disliked of what befell his companions could reach him."

In these difficult circumstances, the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) advised them to migrate:
> The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said to them: **"Indeed, there is a king in the land of Abyssinia with whom no one is wronged. So, go to his land until Allah grants you relief and an escape from your present state."**

---

## The Journey and Arrival of the Migrants

Umm Salamah (may Allah be pleased with her) continued:
> "So we departed for it until we gathered there. We settled in the best of homes with the best of neighbors. **We were safe in our religion and feared no injustice from him.**"

It is said that their departure for Abyssinia took place in **Rajab, in the fifth year of the Prophetic mission.**

**Twelve men and four women** from the Muslims migrated in this exodus. Among them was **Uthman ibn Affan**, who was the first to leave, accompanied by his wife, **Ruqayyah, the daughter of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him).**

events.title: The Second Migration to Abyssinia
events.details:
## Return and Second Migration

The migrants in Abyssinia heard that **Quraysh had embraced Islam**, so they returned to Mecca in **Shawwal of the same year they had migrated**.

> However, when they were a short distance from Mecca and realized the true situation, some of them returned to Abyssinia, and none of the others entered Mecca except secretly or under the protection of a Quraysh man.

Then, the affliction and torment from Quraysh intensified upon them and upon the Muslims, and their tribes oppressed them severely. It was difficult for Quraysh to bear the news of the Negus's good treatment. The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) saw no alternative but to advise his companions to migrate to Abyssinia **a second time**.

The Muslims prepared for the migration again. Quraysh attempted to thwart the second migration, but the Muslims were swifter, reaching the Negus of Abyssinia before they could be overtaken.

**Eighty-three men and eighteen or nineteen women** migrated.

---

## Quraysh's Delegation to the Negus

Quraysh sent **Amr ibn al-Aas and Abdullah ibn Abi Rabee'ah** before they embraced Islam, and they sent with them **rare gifts** for the Negus and his patriarchs. After they arrived before the Negus, they presented him with the gifts, then spoke to him, saying:
> **"O King, indeed some foolish youths have sought refuge in your land. They have abandoned the religion of their people and have not entered your religion. They have come with a religion they invented, which neither we nor you know. The nobles of their people, their fathers, uncles, and tribes, have sent us to you concerning them, so that you may return them to them, for they know them better and are more aware of what they have criticized them for."**

They admonished them in his presence, and the patriarchs said: **"They have spoken truly, O King, so hand them over to them, that they may return them to their people and their lands."**

---

## The Negus's Dialogue with the Muslims

The Negus then sent for the Muslims and invited them. They came, having resolved to **speak nothing but the truth, whatever the consequences.**

The Negus asked them:
> **"What is this religion in which you have separated from your people, and which you have not entered my religion or any of these religions?"**

**Ja'far ibn Abi Talib** (who was the spokesman for the Muslims) replied:
> "O King, we were a people of ignorance; we used to worship idols, eat carrion, commit indecencies, break ties of kinship, treat our neighbors badly, and the strong among us would devour the weak."
>
> He then enumerated the good things that the Prophet (peace be upon him) brought them, and continued: "So we believed him, and had faith in him, and followed him in what he brought us from the religion of Allah. We worshipped Allah alone, associating nothing with Him, and we forbade what was forbidden to us, and permitted what was permitted to us. Then our people rose against us, torturing us and trying to turn us away from our religion, to make us return to the worship of idols instead of worshipping Allah Almighty, and to permit the abominations we used to permit. When they oppressed us, wronged us, made life difficult for us, and came between us and our religion, we came out to your land, choosing you over anyone else, desiring your protection, and hoping that we would not be wronged in your presence, O King."

The Negus asked him: **"Do you have anything with you from what he (Muhammad) brought from Allah?"**
Ja'far replied: **"Yes."**

The Negus said: **"Then recite it to me."**
So he recited to him the beginning of **(Surah Maryam)**.
> The Negus wept until his beard was wet, and his bishops wept until their scriptures were wet when they heard what was recited to them.

---

## The Negus's Decision and Support for the Muslims

Then the Negus said to them:
> **"Indeed, this and what Jesus brought come from the same source. Go, for by Allah, I will not hand them over to you both, nor shall they be harmed"** (addressing Amr ibn al-Aas and his companion).

So they departed. When they left, Amr ibn al-Aas said to Abdullah ibn Abi Rabee'ah:
> **"By Allah, tomorrow I will come to him with something about them that will utterly destroy their flourishing."**

Abdullah ibn Abi Rabee'ah said to him: **"Do not do it, for they have kinship, even if they have differed with us."**
But Amr persisted in his opinion.

The next day, he said to the Negus: **"O King, they say a great thing about Jesus, son of Mary."**

So the Negus sent for them, asking them about their statement concerning the Messiah. They were alarmed, but resolved to speak nothing but the truth, whatever the consequences. When they entered before him and he asked them, Ja'far said to him:
> **"We say concerning him what our Prophet (peace be upon him) brought us: He is the servant of Allah and His Messenger, and His spirit and His word which He cast to Mary the Virgin and the pure."**

The Negus took a stick from the ground and then said:
> **"By Allah, Jesus, son of Mary, did not exceed what you said by this stick."**

His patriarchs grumbled, so he said: **"Even if you grumble!"**
Then he said to the Muslims:
> **"Go, for you are safe in my land – and 'Shuyoom' means 'safe ones' in the Abyssinian language – whoever insults you will be fined, whoever insults you will be fined, whoever insults you will be fined. I would not wish to have a mountain of gold, and yet harm one of you – and 'dabr' means 'mountain' in the Abyssinian language –."**

Then he said to his entourage:
> **"Return their gifts to them, for I have no need of them. By Allah, Allah did not take a bribe from me when He restored my kingdom to me, so I shall not take a bribe concerning it. And the people did not obey me in my matters, so I shall not obey them in this."**

Umm Salamah said:
> **"So they left his presence disgraced, with what they had brought returned to them, and we remained with him in the best of homes with the best of neighbors."**

properties.name: Taif
properties.title: Taif
properties.popupContent: There is a belief that Taif is indirectly referred to in Quran 43:31.[5] The city was visited by the Islamic prophet Muhammad, sometime in the early 7th century, and was inhabited by the tribe of Banu Thaqif. It is still inhabited to this day by their descendants.

events.title: The Prophet's ﷺ Journey to Ta'if
events.details:
## The Journey to Ta'if and the Call to Islam

The Prophet ﷺ set out for Ta'if, which is about **sixty miles** from Mecca. He walked this distance back and forth, accompanied by his freed slave **Zayd ibn Harithah**.

Whenever he passed by a tribe on the way, **he invited them to Islam, but none of them responded positively**.

Upon reaching Ta'if, he **approached its leaders and invited them, but they did not respond**. He stayed among the people of Ta'if for ten days, not leaving any of their noblemen without visiting and speaking to him.

---

## The Harm Inflicted by the Rabble of Ta'if and the Ordeal of Suffering

They told him: **"Get out of our land."** And they incited their foolish people against him.

When he intended to leave, their foolish people and slaves followed him, **insulting him and yelling at him**, until people gathered around him. They stood in **two rows (simatayn)** and began to pelt him with stones and foolish words. **They stoned his ankles until his sandals were stained with blood**.

**Zayd ibn Harithah protected him with his own body** until he sustained head injuries. The foolish people continued to harass him until they forced him into a garden belonging to Utbah and Shaybah, the sons of Rabi'ah, about three miles from Ta'if.

---

## The Prophet's ﷺ Mercy and the Prayer for Guidance

The Messenger of Allah ﷺ returned on the road to Mecca after leaving the garden, **distressed, sorrowful, and broken-hearted**.

When he reached **Qarn al-Manazil**, Allah sent Jibreel (Gabriel) to him, accompanied by the Angel of the Mountains, seeking his permission to **bring down the two mountains (Akhshabayn) upon the people of Mecca**.

The Prophet ﷺ replied:
> **"No, rather I hope that Allah Almighty will bring forth from their loins those who will worship Allah Almighty alone and associate nothing with Him."**

In this response given by the Messenger ﷺ, his **unique personality and his magnificent character are clearly manifested**.

properties.name: Nakhlah
properties.title: Nakhlah
properties.popupContent: Wādī Nakhlah is an area in the Hejazi region of Saudi Arabia between the cities of Mecca and Ta'if, which serves as a Miqat (Boundary) for the Islamic Ḥaram of Mecca.

events.title: The Islam of the Jinn and Their Arrival to the Prophet ﷺ
events.details: ## The Jinn Listen to the Quran When the Prophet ﷺ returned to Mecca from Ta'if, and was in **Nakhlah**, he stood in the middle of the night to pray. A group of Jinn, whom Allah Almighty mentioned, passed by him. They were **seven individuals from the Jinn of Nasibin**. They listened to the Messenger's ﷺ recitation. When he finished his prayer, they returned to their people as warners, having believed and responded to what they heard. Regarding them, Allah Almighty revealed: > ﴿وَإِذْ صَرَفْنَا إِلَيْكَ نَفَرًا مِّنَ الْجِنِّ يَسْتَمِعُونَ الْقُرْآنَ فَلَمَّا حَضَرُوهُ قَالُوا أَنصِتُوا فَلَمَّا قُضِيَ وَلَّوْا إِلَىٰ قَوْمِهِم مُّنذِرِينَ ٢٩ قَالُوا يَا قَوْمَنَا إِنَّا سَمِعْنَا كِتَابًا أُنزِلَ مِن بَعْدِ مُوسَىٰ مُصَدِّقًا لِّمَا بَيْنَ يَدَيْهِ يَهْدِي إِلَى الْحَقِّ وَإِلَىٰ طَرِيقٍ مُّسْتَقِيمٍ ٣٠ يَا قَوْمَنَا أَجِيبُوا دَاعِيَ اللَّهِ وَآمِنُوا بِهِ يَغْفِرْ لَكُم مِّن ذُنُوبِكُمْ وَيُجِرْكُم مِّنْ عَذَابٍ أَلِيمٍ ٣١ وَمَن لَّا يُجِبْ دَاعِيَ اللَّهِ فَلَيْسَ بِمُعْجِزٍ فِي الْأَرْضِ وَلَيْسَ لَهُ مِن دُونِهِ أَوْلِيَاءُ أُولَٰئِكَ فِي ضَلَالٍ مُّبِينٍ ٣٢﴾ > > **Translation of Surah Al-Ahqaf (46), verses 29-32:** > > (29) And [mention, O Muhammad], when We directed to you a group of the jinn, listening to the Quran; and when they attended it, they said, 'Listen quietly.' And when it was concluded, they went back to their people as warners. > > (30) They said, 'O our people, indeed we have heard a Book revealed after Moses, confirming what was before it, guiding to the truth and to a straight path. > > (31) O our people, respond to the caller of Allah and believe in him; He will forgive for you your sins and protect you from a painful punishment.' > > (32) But whoever does not respond to the caller of Allah - he will not cause failure [to Allah] upon earth, and he will not have besides Him any protectors. Those are in clear error. --- ## The Second Delegation of Jinn Several months after the first delegation of Jinn met the Messenger of Allah ﷺ, a second delegation arrived, eager to see the Beloved Chosen One ﷺ and to listen to the words of the Lord of the Worlds.

properties.name: Al Aqabah
properties.title: Al Aqabah
properties.popupContent: It preceded the Hijrah, or migration of Muhammad and his supporters from Mecca, where they were persecuted, to Medina, where Muhammad became ruler. The pledge occurred in 622 CE at a mountain pass (al-ʿaqabah) five kilometers from Mecca.

events.title: The First Pledge of Aqabah
events.details:
**Event Details:**
Narrated by 'Ubadah bin As-Samit (may Allah be pleased with him), one of the leaders on the night of Al-Aqabah: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said while a group of his companions were around him,
> "Swear allegiance to me that you will not associate anything with Allah, nor steal, nor commit adultery, nor kill your children, nor fabricate falsehood which you devise between your hands and feet, nor disobey me in what is good. Whoever among you fulfills this, his reward will be with Allah. Whoever commits any of these and is punished in this world, that will be an expiation for him. Whoever commits any of these and Allah conceals it, then it is up to Allah; if He wills, He will forgive him, and if He wills, He will punish him."

**He ('Ubadah bin As-Samit)** said, "So we swore allegiance to him upon that."

events.title: The Second Pledge of Aqabah
events.details:
**Details of the Event:**
Jabir (may Allah be pleased with him) narrated:
>“The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) stayed in Mecca for ten years, following the people in their dwellings in Ukaz and Majannah, and during the seasons in Mina, saying: **‘Who will shelter me? Who will support me so that I may convey the message of my Lord, and for him will be Paradise?’** Until a man would come from Yemen or from Mudar, and his people would come to him and say: **‘Beware of the youth of Quraish, lest he mislead you.’** And he would walk among their men, and they would point at him with their fingers, until Allah sent us to him from Yathrib. We sheltered him and believed in him. Then a man from us would go out and believe in him and teach him the Quran, then he would return to his family and they would embrace Islam because of his Islam, until there was no house among the dwellings of the Ansar but that there was a group of Muslims in it who openly declared Islam. Then they all consulted together and said: ‘Until when shall we leave the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) to be driven away in the mountains of Mecca, fearing?’ So seventy men of us journeyed to him until they came to him during the season, and we made an appointment with him at Shi'b al-Aqabah. We gathered with him, one or two men at a time, until we were all present, and we said: **‘O Messenger of Allah, we pledge allegiance to you.’** He said: **‘You pledge allegiance to me to listen and obey in times of enthusiasm and disinclination, and to spend in times of hardship and ease, and to enjoin good and forbid evil, and to speak for the sake of Allah, fearing no blame from anyone for the sake of Allah, and to support me and protect me if I come to you from that which you protect your own selves, your wives, and your children, and for you will be Paradise.’** He said: So we stood up to him and pledged allegiance to him. And As'ad ibn Zurarah, who was the youngest of them, took his hand and said: **‘Wait, O people of Yathrib! We have not struck the livers of camels except that we know that he is the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), and that expelling him today means the alienation of all the Arabs, and the killing of your best men, and that the swords will bite you. So either you are a people who can endure that, and your reward will be with Allah, or you are a people who fear for yourselves a calamity, so make that clear, for that will be an excuse for you before Allah.’** They said: **‘Leave us alone, O As'ad! By Allah, we will never forsake this pledge, and we will never withdraw from it.’** He said: So we stood up to him and pledged allegiance to him, and he took our pledge and stipulated conditions for us, and for that he promised us Paradise.”

properties.name: Madinah Al-Taybah
properties.title: Madinah Al-Taybah
properties.popupContent: Madinah has been inhabited at least 1500 years before the Hijra, or approximately the 9th century BCE. By the fourth century, Arab tribes began to encroach from Yemen, and there were three prominent Jewish tribes that inhabited the city around the time of Prophet Muhammad (S.A.W) : the Banu Qaynuqa, the Banu Qurayza, and Banu Nadir.

events.title: The Spread of Islam in Yathrib After the First Pledge of Aqabah
events.details:
**Details of the Event:**
After the first pledge of Al-Aqabah, the Ansar wrote to the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) asking him to send them someone to lead them in prayer and teach them the Quran. So the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) sent them Mus'ab ibn Umayr, who stayed as a guest with As'ad ibn Zurarah. Mus'ab began to call people to Islam, and Islam spread among the people of Yathrib until there was no house in Yathrib but that there was a Muslim man or woman in it. Among those who embraced Islam at his hands were the two leaders of the Aws tribe, Sa'd ibn Mu'adh and Usayd ibn al-Hudayr.

events.title: The Treaty of the Prophet (ﷺ) with the Jews
events.details: **Details of the Event:** Ibn Ishaq said: > "The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) wrote a document between the Muhajireen and the Ansar, in which he made a covenant with the Jews, granting them peace, affirming them in their religion and their possessions, and stipulating conditions for them and upon them." This treaty was established when the Jews refused to follow Islam, and it was before the permission for fighting and taking Jizyah (tribute) from those who refused Islam. Most of them insisted on disbelief. There were three main Jewish tribes in Medina: Banu Qaynuqa', Banu an-Nadir, and Banu Qurayza. All three tribes eventually engaged in hostilities against the Prophet (ﷺ). The Prophet (ﷺ) showed clemency towards Banu Qaynuqa', expelled Banu an-Nadir, and fought and killed the men of Banu Qurayza, taking their descendants captive due to their treachery. Regarding these events, Allah revealed: **Surah Al-Hashr (Chapter of the Gathering), which describes the expulsion of Banu an-Nadir:** > ﴿هُوَ الَّذِي أَخْرَجَ الَّذِينَ كَفَرُوا مِنْ أَهْلِ الْكِتَابِ مِن دِيَارِهِمْ لِأَوَّلِ الْحَشْرِ ٢﴾ "It is He who expelled the ones who disbelieved among the People of the Scripture from their homes at the first gathering." **Surah Al-Ahzab (Chapter of the Confederates), which addresses the treachery of Banu Qurayza during the Battle of the Trench:** > ﴿وَأَنزَلَ الَّذِينَ ظَاهَرُوهُم مِّنْ أَهْلِ الْكِتَابِ مِن صَيَاصِيهِمْ وَقَذَفَ فِي قُلُوبِهِمُ الرُّعْبَ فَرِيقًا تَقْتُلُونَ وَتَأْسِرُونَ فَرِيقًا ٢٦﴾ "And He brought down those who supported them among the People of the Scripture from their fortresses and cast terror into their hearts. A party you killed, and a party you took captive."

events.title: The Legislation of the Adhan
events.details:
**Details of the Event:** Narrated Abdullah ibn Umar (may Allah be pleased with him): > "When the Muslims arrived in Medina, they would gather and estimate the times for prayers, and no one would call out for it. One day, they discussed this matter. Some suggested taking a bell like the Christians' bell, while others suggested a horn like the Jews' horn." Then Abdullah ibn Zayd (may Allah be pleased with him) narrated his dream, saying: > "When the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) ordered a bell to be made to be struck for the people to gather for prayer, a man appeared to me in a dream while I was asleep, carrying a bell in his hand. I said: 'O servant of Allah, will you sell this bell?' He said: 'What will you do with it?' I replied: 'We will call to prayer with it.' He said: 'Shall I not tell you of something better than that?' I said to him: 'Yes!' He then said: 'You should say: > > > اللَّهُ أَكْبَرُ، اللَّهُ أَكْبَرُ، اللَّهُ أَكْبَرُ، اللَّهُ أَكْبَرُ،
> أَشْهَدُ أَن لا إِلَهَ إِلاَّ اللَّهُ، أَشْهَدُ أَن لا إِلَهَ إِلاَّ اللَّهُ،
> أَشْهَدُ أَنَّ مُحَمَّدًا رَسُولُ اللَّهِ، أَشْهَدُ أَنَّ مُحَمَّدًا رَسُولُ اللَّهِ،
> حَيَّ عَلَى الصَّلاةِ، حَيَّ عَلَى الصَّلاةِ،
> حَيَّ عَلَى الْفَلاحِ، حَيَّ عَلَى الْفَلاحِ،
> اللَّهُ أَكْبَرُ، اللَّهُ أَكْبَرُ،
> لا إِلَهَ إِلاَّ اللَّهُ. > > > Then he moved a little distance from me and said: 'And when you stand for prayer (i.e., for the Iqamah), you should say: > > > اللَّهُ أَكْبَرُ، اللَّهُ أَكْبَرُ،
> أَشْهَدُ أَن لا إِلَهَ إِلاَّ اللَّهُ، أَشْهَدُ أَنَّ مُحَمَّدًا رَسُولُ اللَّهِ،
> حَيَّ عَلَى الصَّلاةِ، حَيَّ عَلَى الْفَلاحِ،
> قَدْ قَامَتِ الصَّلاةُ، قَدْ قَامَتِ الصَّلاةُ،
> اللَّهُ أَكْبَرُ، اللَّهُ أَكْبَرُ،
> لا إِلَهَ إِلاَّ اللَّهُ. > > > When I awoke, I came to the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and informed him of what I had seen. He said: 'Indeed, it is a true dream, if Allah wills. Stand with Bilal and convey to him what you have seen, and let him call the Adhan with it, for he has a louder voice than you.' So I stood with Bilal, and I began to convey it to him, and he would call the Adhan with it. Abdullah ibn Zayd said: Umar ibn al-Khattab heard that while he was in his house, so he came out dragging his garment, saying: 'By the One who sent you with the truth, O Messenger of Allah, I have seen exactly what he saw!' The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: 'All praise is due to Allah!'"

events.title: The Migration of the Companions to Medina
events.details: **Details of the Event:** After the Second Pledge of Aqabah was concluded, the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) commanded those with him to migrate to Medina. So, they began to leave in groups. Among the first to migrate after the Second Pledge of Aqabah was Mus'ab ibn Umayr. Then came Amir ibn Rabi'ah, an ally of Banu Adi ibn Ka'b, along with his wife Layla bint Abi Hathmah ibn Ghanim. Following them was Abdullah ibn Jahsh with his family and his brother Abd ibn Jahsh (also known as Abu Ahmad), who was blind. Their residences, along with that of Abu Salamah, were in Quba, among Banu Amr ibn Awf. When all of Banu Jahsh migrated with their women, Abu Sufyan seized their empty house in Mecca. When news of this reached Abdullah ibn Jahsh, he mentioned it to the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said to him: > "Are you not pleased, O Abdullah, that Allah will give you a house in Paradise better than it?" Abdullah replied: "Yes!" The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "Then that is for you." Later, when the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) conquered Mecca, Abu Ahmad (Abdullah ibn Jahsh's brother) spoke to him about their house, but the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) hesitated to address it. The people then told Abu Ahmad: "O Abu Ahmad, the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) dislikes that you should seek to reclaim anything you sacrificed for the sake of Allah." So, he refrained from speaking to the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) about it. All of Banu Ghanim ibn Dudan were Muslims and had all migrated to Medina. Then, Umar ibn al-Khattab and Ayyash ibn Abi Rabi'ah migrated with twenty riders and arrived in Medina. Hisham ibn al-As ibn Wa'il had also embraced Islam and promised Umar ibn al-Khattab that he would migrate with him. He said: "You will find me, or I will find you, at Ada'ah of Banu Ghifar." However, Hisham's people became aware of his intention and detained him, preventing his migration. Then, Abu Jahl and Al-Harith ibn Hisham left Mecca and reached Medina while the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) was still in Mecca. They spoke to Ayyash ibn Abi Rabi'ah, who was their maternal half-brother and cousin. They informed him that his mother had vowed not to wash her head or seek shade until she saw him. Ayyash felt pity for his mother and believed them, so he set out to return with them. On the way, they tied him up and brought him to Mecca in broad daylight, bound. Then they said: "O people of Mecca, do this with your foolish ones just as we have done with our foolish one!" They imprisoned him there until Allah rescued him later through the supplication of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) during the Qunut prayer: > اللَّهُمَّ أَنْجِ الْوَلِيدَ بْنَ الْوَلِيدِ، وَسَلَمَةَ بْنَ هِشَامٍ، وَعَيَّاشَ بْنَ أَبِي رَبِيعَةَ. "O Allah, save Al-Walid ibn Al-Walid, Salamah ibn Hisham, and Ayyash ibn Abi Rabi'ah." When Suhayb ibn Sinan intended to migrate, the disbelievers of Quraish said to him: "You came to us as a poor, lowly person, and your wealth grew with us, and you reached the position you reached. Now you want to leave with your wealth and yourself? No, by Allah, that will not happen!" Suhayb said to them: "What if I give you all my wealth, will you clear my way?" They said: "Yes." So he said: "Indeed, I have given it to you." When this news reached the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), he said: > "Suhayb has profited! Suhayb has profited!" Then the Muhajireen continued to migrate to Medina until the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) himself migrated.

events.title: Construction of the Prophet's Mosque
events.details:
**Details of the Event:** The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) rode his she-camel from Quba, and people walked alongside him until it knelt down at the place of the Messenger's Mosque in Medina, where some Muslims were already praying. This site was a date drying ground (Mirbad) belonging to two orphan boys, Sahl and Suhayl, who were under the guardianship of As'ad ibn Zurarah. When his she-camel knelt, the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: > «هَذَا إِنْ شَاءَ اللَّهُ الْمَنْزِلُ» > > "This, if Allah wills, is the lodging place." Then the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) called the two boys and negotiated with them to buy the Mirbad to make it a mosque. They said: "No, rather we gift it to you, O Messenger of Allah!" But the Messenger of Allah refused to accept it as a gift until he bought it from them. Then he built it into a mosque. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) began to carry bricks with them during its construction, and while carrying the bricks, he would say: > هَذَا الْحِمَالُ لَا حِمَالَ خَيْبَرْ، هَذَا أَبَرُّ رَبَّنَا وَأَطْهَرْ. > > "This burden is not like the burden of Khaybar;
> This is more righteous from our Lord and purer." And he would say: > اللَّهُمَّ إِنَّ الْأَجْرَ أَجْرُ الْآخِرَهْ، فَارْحَمِ الْأَنْصَارَ، وَالمُهَاجِرَهْ. > > "O Allah, indeed the reward is the reward of the Hereafter,
> So have mercy on the Ansar and the Muhajirin." Anas ibn Malik (may Allah be pleased with him) narrated: > "The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) arrived in Medina and stayed in the upper part of Medina, in a quarter called Banu Amr ibn Awf. The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) stayed there for fourteen nights. Then he sent for Banu al-Najjar, and they came carrying swords. I can almost see the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) on his riding camel, with Abu Bakr riding behind him, and the nobles of Banu al-Najjar surrounding him until he dismounted in the courtyard of Abu Ayyub's house. The Prophet loved to pray wherever the prayer time found him, and he would pray even in sheep pens. He then ordered the construction of the Mosque. He sent for the leaders of Banu al-Najjar and said: > > «يَا بَنِي النَّجَّارِ ثَامِنُونِي بِحَائِطِكُمْ هَذَا» > > 'O Banu al-Najjar, name a price for this garden of yours.' > > They said: 'No, by Allah, we seek no price for it except from Allah.' Anas said: 'It contained what I am telling you: graves of polytheists, ruins, and date palms. The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) ordered the graves of the polytheists to be dug up, then the ruins to be leveled, and the date palms to be cut down. They then arranged the date palms towards the Qiblah of the Mosque, and made its doorposts of stones. They began to carry rocks while reciting chants, and the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) was with them, saying: > > اللَّهُمَّ لَا خَيْرَ إِلَّا خَيْرُ الآخِرَهْ، فَاغْفِرْ لِلأَنْصَارِ وَالمُهَاجِرَهْ. > > 'O Allah, there is no good but the good of the Hereafter,
> So forgive the Ansar and the Muhajirin.'" Abdullah ibn Umar said: > "Indeed, the Mosque during the time of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) was built with bricks, its roof was of palm fronds, and its pillars were of palm wood."

events.title: The Brotherhood between the Muhajirin and Ansar
events.details: **Details of the Event:** Among the profound effects of the migration of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and his companions to Medina was the **brotherhood** established between the Muhajirin (Emigrants) and the Ansar (Helpers) (may Allah be pleased with them). This bond was so strong that, in the early stages, they even inherited from each other. Ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with him) said regarding the verse: > {وَلِكُلٍّ جَعَلْنَا مَوَالِيَ} > > "{And for all, We have made inheritors...}" (Quran 4:33) > He explained: > "It means **inheritors**. And as for: > > {وَالَّذِينَ عَاقَدَتْ أَيْمَانُكُمْ} > > '{And those with whom you have made a solemn covenant...}' (Quran 4:33) > > He said: 'When the Muhajirin came to Medina, the Muhajir would inherit from the Ansari, to the exclusion of his blood relatives, due to the brotherhood that the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) had established between them. But when the verse: > > {وَلِكُلٍّ جَعَلْنَا مَوَالِيَ} > > '{And for all, We have made inheritors...}' was revealed, it abrogated that inheritance.' Then he said regarding: > > {وَالَّذِينَ عَاقَدَتْ أَيْمَانُكُمْ} > > '{And those with whom you have made a solemn covenant...}' > > 'This refers only to mutual support, provision, and advice; the inheritance has been abolished, but a bequest can still be made to them.'" Anas (may Allah be pleased with him) said: > "When the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) came to Medina, the Muhajirin came to him and said: 'O Messenger of Allah, we have not seen any people more generous with much, nor better in sharing from little, than the people among whom we have settled. They have spared us effort and included us in their comfort, so much so that we fear they will take all the reward!' The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: > > «لَا، مَا دَعَوْتُمُ اللَّهَ لَهُمْ، وَأَثْنَيْتُمْ عَلَيْهِمْ» > > 'No, not as long as you supplicate to Allah for them and praise them.'" Abdur-Rahman ibn Awf (may Allah be pleased with him) narrated: > "When we came to Medina, the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) established brotherhood between me and Sa'd ibn ar-Rabi'. Sa'd ibn ar-Rabi' said: 'I am the wealthiest of the Ansar, so I will divide half of my wealth for you. And look at whichever of my two wives you desire, and I will divorce her for you, so when her waiting period ends, you may marry her.' Abdur-Rahman replied to him: 'I have no need for that. Is there a market where there is trade?' Sa'd said: 'The market of Banu Qaynuqa'.' Abdur-Rahman said: 'So Abdur-Rahman went to it early in the morning, and he came back with dried yogurt and clarified butter.' Abdur-Rahman continued: 'Then he continued going early, and it was not long before Abdur-Rahman came with traces of yellowish perfume on him.' The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) asked: > > «تَزَوَّجْتَ؟» > > 'Have you married?' > > He said: 'Yes.' He asked: > > «وَمَنْ؟» > > 'And whom?' > > He said: 'A woman from the Ansar.' He asked: > > «كَمْ سُقْتَ؟» > > 'How much dowry did you give?' > > He said: 'The weight of a date-stone in gold – or a date-stone of gold.' Then the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said to him: > > «أَوْلِمْ وَلَوْ بِشَاةٍ» > > 'Hold a wedding feast, even if it is with a single sheep.'"

events.title: The Conversion of Abdullah ibn Salam
events.details:
**Details of the Event:**

Abdullah ibn Salam (may Allah be pleased with him) was a learned scholar among the Jews. He narrated his journey to Islam, saying:

> When I heard about the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), I recognized his description, his name, and the time he was expected to appear, which we had been awaiting. I kept this knowledge to myself, silent about it, until the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) arrived in Medina. When he disembarked in Quba, among the Banu Amr ibn Awf, a man came and informed me of his arrival. I was at the top of my date palm, working, with my aunt Khalidah bint Al-Harith sitting beneath me. When I heard the news of the Messenger of Allah's (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) arrival, I exclaimed 'Allahu Akbar' (Allah is the Greatest)! My aunt, upon hearing my exclamation, said to me: 'May Allah disappoint you! By Allah, had you heard of Musa ibn Imran coming, you would not have exclaimed more!' I replied to her: 'O aunt, by Allah, he is the brother of Musa ibn Imran, and he is upon his religion, sent with what Musa was sent with.' She then asked: 'O son of my brother, is he the Prophet about whom we were told he would be sent just before the Hour?' I said to her: 'Yes.' She replied: 'Then that is he.'

Abdullah ibn Salam continued:

> "Then I went out to the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and accepted Islam. After that, I returned to my household and commanded them, and they too embraced Islam."

He further recounted:

> I kept my conversion a secret from the Jews. Then I came to the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and said to him: 'O Messenger of Allah, the Jews are a people of slander, and I would like you to let me hide in one of your houses, concealed from them. Then you can ask them about me, so they may tell you how I am among them, before they know about my conversion; for if they knew, they would slander and defame me.' So, the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) let me enter one of his houses. The Jews then came to him, spoke with him, and questioned him. Then he asked them: 'What kind of man is Abdullah ibn Salam among you?' They replied: 'He is our master and the son of our master, our scholar and our wise man.' When they finished their praises, I came out before them and said to them: 'O assembly of Jews, fear Allah and accept what has come to you! By Allah, you certainly know that he is the Messenger of Allah, you find him written with his name and description in the Torah with you. Indeed, I bear witness that he is the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him), and I believe in him, affirm him, and recognize him.' They immediately responded: 'You lied!' Then they began to revile me. I then said to the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): 'Did I not tell you, O Messenger of Allah, that they are a slanderous people, treacherous, liars, and corrupt!' Then I openly declared my Islam and the Islam of my household, and my aunt Khalidah bint Al-Harith also embraced Islam, and her Islam was excellent.

events.title: Construction of Quba Mosque
events.details:
**Details of the Event:**

The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) stayed with Banu Amr ibn Awf in **Quba** for over ten nights. During this time, he laid the foundation of the mosque that was **"founded upon piety"** (referencing Quran 9:108), and he prayed in it.
